newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Stanbic sees better interest margins in '97.
newsitem.headline: Stanbic sees better interest margins in '97.

text.p: Standard Bank Investment Corp said on Tuesday it was optimistic that a continuous improvement in money market conditions would see a normalisation in interest margins during the year.

"We've seen a progressive improvement in the money market situation since the second week in January and there is a sense that we will see more normal (interest) margins this year," Stanbic group Chief Executive Mike Vosloo said at the group's annual results presentation on Tuesday.
"We're not quite where we would like to be but the signs are positive," he said.

In the year ended December 31 the banking group -- South Africa's second largest in terms of assets -- showed headline earnings per share rising to 1,311 cents from 1,053 cents previously, while the dividend climbed to 407 cents compared with 327 cents.
Vosloo said there were indications that government's fiscal policy was coming in line with monetary policy.
"Looking ahead, underpinning economic fundamentals are becoming more attractive for our kind of industry," he said.

The group's interest margins came under pressure for the year to December due to difficult conditions in the domestic money market in the second half of 1996 -- particularly in the last quarter -- which saw short-term interest rates soar and a continuous squeeze in the daily money market shortage.
Vosloo said extremely tight money market conditions and continued downward pressure on the rand restricted growth in net interest income -- the bugbear of the year -- to 10 per cent for the year.
He said growing trade-related offshore lending balances at low margins combined with strong growth in domestic high quality low margin assets also added to lower group margins.
Growth in home loans picked up during the year and mortgages were becoming an important focus area, Vosloo said.
"We took our eye off home loans earlier last year but the situation has now turned around and mortgages are becoming an important aspect of our business," he said.
Income from associates was 222 million rand -- significantly higher than in 1995 -- due to a change by associate Liberty Life Association of Africa Ltd to the valuation of its life fund.
Group assets grew by 26 percent and loans and advances by 19 percent, recording strong growth in corporate loans, instalment sale finance, card debtors and home loans, Vosloo said.
